author: siladu
content:
Question for CLs...for getPayloadBodies* methods, what are the typical number of blocks you will be requesting and **how often**? 

Trying to understand the performance impact especially since engine API is synchronous (at least it currently is for besu, although maybe these new methods shouldn't be).

cc. <@1016224469704003675>

author: sproul
content:
we request them only when peers are syncing from us, the observed rate in the wild seems to be about 3-4/s on average, so quite a lot

usually we'll fetch batches of 32-64 at a time

author: parithosh
content:
Regarding public testnet, would client teams feel comfortable if we got genesis configs out on monday. We set genesis to happen on wednesday/thursday and shapella to hit the tuesday after? That way client teams would still get all of next week to merge fixes and push changes. Users would also get a few days to perform deposits and test changes pre-capella. 

If there are some unresolved topics, then we can of course push the whole plan by a week (or as needed).

content: One thing we could do is fuzz on both different things in the interest of time, perhaps exits on one and blst changes on the other <@861686400893583370>, if we send over 55% of bad blocks on devnet 4 Danny agrees that it's good enough to test non-finality

author: barnabasbusa
content:
This is what we were thinking:```Public testnet:
* 5 bootnode, 2lh, 1teku, 1 prysm, 1 nimbus. 
* 8 node prysm 2x(geth,nethermind,erigon,besu) - 2k validator each - 16k
* 8 node lighthouse 2x(geth,nethermind,erigon,besu) - 2k validator each - 16k
* 4 node nimbus (geth,nethermind,erigon,besu) - 2k validator each - 8k
* 4 node teku (geth,nethermind,erigon,besu) - 2k validator each - 8k
* 5 node lodestar (geth,nethermind,erigon,besu,ethereumjs) - 2k validator each - 10k
----
58k total EF validator
assign 2k to Jim```

author: barnabasbusa
content: I'd like to disagree with that

author: potuz
content: Sounds very good to me... will wait for others to chime in if they think this public testnet needs to have some load. Actually I like the fact that it's relatively small, perhaps users getting in and exiting makes for a nice test
